Award.AwardTitle: Fourth Mile High Conference on Nonassociative Mathematics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the Fourth Mile High Conference on Nonassociative Mathematics which will take place at the University of Denver, Denver, Colorado, on July 29--August 5, 2017. Approximately 90 researchers from 20 countries are expected to participate. The conference will bring together scientists from all areas of nonassociative mathematics and is intended to promote cross-disciplinary research. The conference will be accessible to graduate and post-doctoral students and will provide a forum for these beginning researchers. The organizers are committed to encouraging and supporting participation of researchers from underrepresented and underprivileged groups.

Nonassociative mathematics is a broad field that interacts with many traditional mathematical disciplines. The following areas of mathematics will be featured at the conference: the algebraic theory of quasigroups, loops, Lie algebras and Jordan algebras; the combinatorial theory of latin squares and triple systems; the geometric theory of 3-nets and latin square designs; applications of octonions and related structures in physics; applications of quandles in knot theory. The meeting will begin with a full day of expository lectures on the connections between low-dimensional topology and related self-distributive algebras. Further information can be found on the conference website: www.math.du.edu/milehigh

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Fourth Mile High Conference on Nonassociative Mathematics took place at the University of Denver, Denver, Colorado, July 29 - August 5, 2017. There were 55 participants from 15 countries. Fifteen participants of the conference were graduate students or postdoctoral scholars.

The conference covered all aspects of nonassociative mathematics, including quasigroups, loops, latin squares, Lie algebras, Jordan algebras, octonions, quandles and their applications.

The program and organizing committee of the conference consisted of:

  • Murray Bremner (University of Saskatchewan, Canada)
  • Scott Carter (University of South Alabama, USA)
  • Anthony Evans (Wright State University, USA)
  • John Huerta (University of Lisbon, Portugal)
  • Michael Kinyon (University of Denver, USA)
  • Eric Moorhouse (University of Wyoming, USA)
  • Jonathan Smith (Iowa State University, USA)
  • Petr Vojt?chovský (University of Denver, USA)

The conference opened with a tutorial day on self-distributive structures, set-theoretical solutions of the Yang-Baxter equation and their applications to low-dimensional topology. In the remaining days, 42 talks were presented, including the following 7 main talks:

  • Alissa Crans, Knots and links with finite n-quandles
  • Jaromy Kuhl, Completing partial latin squares
  • Vladimir Dotsenko, Pre-Lie algebras and F-manifolds
  • Michael Duff, A magic pyramid of supergravities
  • Andrew Linshaw, Introduction to vertex algebras and a classification problem
  • Susanne Pumplün, Nonassociative algebras obtained from skew polynomial rings and their applications
  • Andrei Zavarnitsine, On Moufang loops and related groups

The conference concluded with an open problem session.

The proceedings of the conference will appear as a volume titled “Nonassociative Mathematics and its Applications” of the series Contemporary Mathematics published by the American Mathematical Society. The members of the program and organizing committee of the conference served as guest editors for the proceedings.


Last Modified: 10/03/2018
Modified by: Petr Vojtechovsky
